CWT 375.48 3885.74 2938.76 946.98 CT 224.17 2312.44 1921.28 391.16 Pb-CWT 116.32 1201.95 813.38 388.57 Pb-CT 52.59 529.85 358.33 171.52 The enhanced Pb resistance of CeO2/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 by the modification with W Ye Jiang Conceptualization Methodology Writing – original draft Investigation a Lin Yang Validation Formal analysis Investigation Resources Writing – original draft a Da Han Writing – original draft Data curation Investigation a Zhengda Yang Supervision Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Congcong Su Data curation Investigation Visualization Writing – review & editing a Riyi Lin Writing – review & editing a Xinwei Wang Writing – review & editing a Xinbo Zhu Writing – review & editing b a College of New energy, China University of Petroleum (East China), 66 West Changjiang Road, Qingdao 266580, China College of New energy China University of Petroleum (East China) 66 West Changjiang Road Qingdao 266580 China aCollege of New energy, China University of Petroleum (East China), 66 West Changjiang Road, Qingdao 266580, China b Faculty of Maritime and Transportation, Ningbo University, Ningbo 315211, China Faculty of Maritime and Transportation Ningbo University Ningbo 315211 China bFaculty of Maritime and Transportation, Ningbo University, Ningbo 315211, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The novel CeO2/TiO2 catalysts were modified by W in this work. It revealed that W modification could significantly facilitate the capacity of CeO2/TiO2 catalyst for resisting Pb poisoning. And various characterizations were applied to explore the underlying resistance mechanism. XPS and H2-TPR analysis revealed that the W modification promoted the transformation from surface Ce4+ to Ce3+. Then the increased surface Ce3+ along with highly dispersed W species provided more Brønsted acid sites for NH3 adsorption on the surface of CeO2/TiO2 catalyst (NH3-TPD and DFT). By XPS and NO+O2 co-adsorption results, the oxidation of NO to NO2 was motivated due to the increased surface chemisorbed oxygen. Furthermore, both E-R and L-H mechanisms were suitable for the NH3-SCR reaction over CWT and CT catalysts according to in situ DRIFT analysis. The deposition of PbO merely inhibited the NH3 and NO x adsorption, while the NH3-SCR mechanism wasn't changed. Key words NH3-SCR CeO2/TiO2 W modification PbO resistance 1 Introduction As one of the major stationary source emissions, NO x (nitrogen oxides) will cause multitudinous environmental issues comprising acid precipitation, ozone destruction, photochemistry smog and global warming [1–3]. NH3-SCR (selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3) has been regarded as the most advanced technique for NO x removal from stationary emission on account of its brilliant denitration properties [4,5]. Vanadia-titania catalysts modified by W or Mo have been implemented regularly over the last several decades due to their excellent SCR activity [6,7]. However, some defects are unavoidable in their practical application, such as the poisonousness of vanadium, the limited activation temperature, the inferor tolerance to complex flue gas and high N2O generation at high temperature [8–10]. As the prospective substitutes for commercial vanadia-titania based SCR catalysts, ceria-based catalysts possessed prominent oxygen storage-release capacity and reducibility [9,10]. For the past decades, extensive attention has been given to the investigation of ceria-based catalysts, such as CeO2-TiO2, CeO2−MnO x , Ce-P-O and CeO2−MoO3 [11–14]. Municipal solid waste (MSW) incineration has grown rapidly all over the world and its NO x emission has a magnitude equal to that of coal-powered electrical plants [15]. And some developed countries have achieved the practical application of NH3-SCR technology to control the NO x emission from MSW plants due to the stringent NO x emission restrictions. Nonetheless, the existence of numerous heavy metals in the flue gas will reduce the performance and longevity of SCR catalysts [16]. As one of typical poisonous species, lead (Pb) generally exists in PbO form in the exhaust gas in both MSW incineration and coal-fired plants [17]. The concentration of Pb from some MSW incineration flue gasses before electrostatic precipitator (ESP) could reach 6–40 mg/g [18]. In addition, the lead loading over vanadia-titania based catalysts was up to 3350 ppm after the 80 days operating period in a MSW incinerator [19]. Therefore, the impact of Pb on NH3-SCR catalysts has brought about the widespread attention. Chen et al. [20] reported that the deactivation impact of PbO on V2O5/TiO2 catalyst ranked second only to that of K2O. Based on the research of Khodayari and Odenbrand [21], the deactivation of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts by PbO resulted from its rivalrous adsorption on active sites. Furthermore, PbO could expand the TiO2 nanoparticles and lessen the amount of chemisorbed oxygen, thus greatly reducing its SCR activity [22]. Zhou et al. [23] found that the activity decline of Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst by PbO was ascribed to the suppressive NH3 adsorption on the catalyst surface. In our previous study [24], the decrease in the number of Brønsted acid sites and the suppression of NO oxidation to NO2 were regarded as two key factors accounting for the reduced SCR activity of CeO2/TiO2 catalyst due to PbO. Considering the wide application prospects of CeO2/TiO2 catalyst in the future and the serious poisoning impact of Pb on SCR catalysts, it is imperative to enhance the Pb resistance of CeO2/TiO2 catalyst. Previous studies demonstrated that the introduction of W could effectively protect CeO2 nanoparticles from the deactivation of alkaline metal, arsenic and SO2 [25,26]. Thus W is likely to be a proper promoter to ameliorate the deactivation of CeO2/TiO2 catalyst by Pb species, which has been rarely investigated to our knowledge. In this work, the CeO2/TiO2 catalyst was modified by W to investigate its capacity for enhancing its resistance against Pb poisoning. And various characterizations and density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out to elucidate the role of W in resisting the Pb poisoning of CeO2/TiO2 catalyst in NH3-SCR reaction. 2 Experiments 2.1 Catalysts preparation A sol-gel method was adopted to obtain the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst according to the following steps. Firstly, the solution A was obtained by mixing adequately anhydrous ethanol (136 ml) with tetra-n-butyl titanate (34 ml). Subsequently, ammonium metatungstate (0.879 g) and cerium nitrate (4.010 g) were dissolved in the solution containing DI water (68 ml), absolute ethyl alcohol (68 ml) and aqua fortis (6.8 ml) to obtain solution B. Afterwards, the solution A was added into B with the aid of hose pump to keep the constant speed of 2 ml/min. Then canary yellow transparent sol was formed with continuous stirring for 3 h, followed by drying (80 °C, 24 h) and calcination (500 °C, 5 h) to achieve CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. It was labeled as CWT, where the mass ratio of CeO2/WO3/TiO2 was 2:1:10. Similarly, the CeO2/TiO2 catalyst was synthesized and the mass ratio of CeO2/TiO2 was 2:10, which was labeled as CT. The Pb-poisoning catalyst samples with Pb/Ce molar ratio of 0.1:1 (labeled as Pb(0.1)-CWT and Pb(0.1)-CT) or 0.5:1 (labeled as Pb-CWT and Pb-CT) were prepared by an impregnation method. Briefly, the dry powder catalysts were firstly impregnated in the solution containing precise quality of Pb(NO3)2. Then the digital water bath kettle was applied to heat the mixed liquor (70 °C) with constant agitation to obtain the pale yellow mash. After maintained for 24 h in ambient temperature, the pale yellow mash was dried (12 h, 110 °C) and calcined (5 h, 500 °C). 2.2 Catalytic activity test In SCR performance measurements, a fixed-bed quartz reactor of 8 mm inner diameter was employed at standard atmosphere condition. The feed gas was composed of 1000 ppm NH3, 3 vol.% O2 and 1000 ppm NO in N2 atmosphere. In addition, the total gas flow was set as 500 ml/min with the GHSV of 90,000 h − 1. And a 350 Pro-Testo flue gas analyzer was employed to record the concentrations of effluent gasses such as O2 and NO x . 2.3 Catalysts characterization The textural properties of samples were acquired on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument using N2 at 77 K. The crystalline structure of samples was measured by a Rigaku D/max-2200/PC apparatus using Cu Ka irradiation. A Thermo ESCALAB 250 electronic spectrograph equipped with Al Ka radiation source was applied to carry out the X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS). And the binding energy calibration was based on the carbon deposit C1S line (BE = 284.8 eV). By use of an automated chemisorption instrument (FINESORB-3010), the programmed reduction of H2 and programmed desorption of NH3 was conducted as a function of temperature, which was, respectively aliased as H2-TPR and NH3-TPD. Before H2-TPR experiments, appropriate quality of test samples were pretreated in Ar atmosphere (500 °C, 1 h) and then 10 vol.% H2/Ar mixture (30 ml/min) was introduced by ramping the temperature with a rate of 10 °C/min from indoor temperature to 700 °C. Meanwhile, the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) would record the H2 consumption. During NH3-TPD experiments, appropriate amount of test samples were firstly exposed to He atmosphere (500 °C, 1 h) and then pure ammonia (30 ml/min) was aerated until the adsorption of catalysts was saturated, subsequently purified with He to remove excess absorbed species. The temperature was raised from indoor temperature to 700 °C (10 °C/min). Simultaneously, the TCD collected the amount of NH3 desorption. A Thermo Nicolet iS 50 FTIR spectrometer was used to carry out in situ DRIFT experiment, which was equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride detector. The gas flow as well as concentration of various gas (if used) was absolutely the same as that of SCR performance. Briefly, the samples were initially treated in flowing N2 atmosphere (400 °C, 2 h), followed by cooled to 50 °C. As the samples cooled off, the spectral background was monitored and eliminated from the recorded spectrum. 2.4 Computational details The (001) anatase plane was used for the catalyst surface due to its low stability. The XRD results showed that CeO2 crystals were not found on the CeO2-TiO2 surface (see Fig. 12). Accordingly, the CeO2-TiO2 model was established by replacing a Ti atom with a Ce atom. The whole calculations were performed using double-numerical plus polarization (DNP) functions and GGA-PBE. The core electrons were treated with DFT Semicore Pseudopots (DSPP). The real space cutoff radius was maintained at 5.0 Å. A Monkhorst-Pack grid of size of (2×2×1) was used to the surface Brillouin zone of the whole system. For avoiding the interactions of the surfaces, a 15 Å vacuum layer in the z-direction was applied. The energy and displacement convergence criteria for geometric optimization were 1×10−5 Ha and 5×10−3 Å, respectively. The adsorption energy (E ad) was defined in Eq. (2): E a d = E t o t a l − E s u r f a c e − E a d s o r b a t e where E total, E surface, and E adsorbate represented the energy of surface and isolated molecular, pure surface, and isolated molecules, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NO conversion over catalysts The NO conversion over the fresh and Pb-poisoning samples as a function of reaction temperature is displayed in Fig. 1 . Both the fresh CWT and CT catalysts exhibited superior SCR performance in the temperature range from 250 °C to 450 °C, and the addition of W could noticeably improve the catalytic activity of CT and enlarge its temperature window. After the introduction of Pb, NO conversion decreased with increasing PbO loadings over CT or CWT. As for the Pb-CT, the NO conversion was below 20% over the whole temperature range. Compared with the Pb-CT, the deactivation of Pb-CWT was relatively weaker and the highest NO conversion could reach up to 60% at 450 °C. It could be found that the presence of W could conspicuously retard the deactivation of CT at the same Pb loading. In particular, the NO conversion of Pb-CT was negative at 500 °C, which could be ascribed to the promoted CO reaction at high temperature (4NH3+5O2→4NO+6H2O) [27]. The above results manifested that the modification of CT catalyst by W could boost its resistance to Pb poisoning significantly. 3.2 XRD results XRD analysis was carried out to research the crystal structures of the four samples, and the consequences are presented in Fig. 2 . Obviously, only anatase TiO2 characteristic diffraction peaks were detected over all the samples. It demonstrated that Ce, W (for CWT and Pb-CWT) and Pb (for Pb-CT and Pb-CWT) species existed as a highly dispersed or amorphous state on the surface of the catalysts. The peak intensity of CWT was higher than that of CT, indicating that the introduction of W elevated the crystallinity over CT. This could be attributed to the significant interaction among Ce, W and Ti species [28]. As for two poisoning samples, the XRD spectra weren't altered apparently, implying that the introduction of Pb had almost no impact on the crystal structures of CWT and CT. It also showed that the dispersion of active species on support TiO2 was not changed significantly. 3.3 BET results Fig. 3 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the four samples. Based on the IUPAC classification [29], all the samples displayed IV isotherms and H1 hysteresis loops, which were representative of mesoporous materials. From Fig. 3(A), it could be seen that the pore size distributions of CT and CWT were centered at about 8.9 nm and 6.1 nm, respectively. It was conspicuous that the pore size of CT became smaller after the doping of W. When Pb was deposited on the fresh CT and CWT, their pore size distribution shifted to higher values and their pore volume diminished. It further confirmed that Pb could result in the pore blocking of CT and CWT. The BET results of the fresh and Pb-poisoning samples are shown in Table 1 . It could be seen that the fresh CWT and CT catalysts possessed large BET surface area and total pore volume. This might be to the benefit of the good dispersion of active species (see Fig. 2) and could further facilitate the NH3-SCR reaction. After the doping of Pb, a remarkable decline in total pore volume and BET surface area could be observed. Nevertheless, the average pore diameter enlarged evidently for two poisoning samples. These results indicated that the doping of Pb destroyed the pore structure of the fresh samples, leading to the decrease in mesopores along with the increase in macropores [30]. It agreed well with the pore size distribution in Fig. 3(A). Compared with the BET and activity results, it was found that the variation in the BET surface area was the same as that in the catalytic activity while the total pore volume and average pore diameter did not showed similar tendency. Accordingly, the structural properties weren't seemingly a critical factor responsible for the deactivation by Pb and the enhanced Pb resistance by W. 3.4 XPS results The element compositions and chemical states on the catalyst surface of the four samples were identified by XPS. The relative concentrations of all elements on the catalyst surface are summarized in Table 2 . In comparison with CT, the surface concentration of Ce on CWT was higher, which could be attributed to the interaction among Ce species, W species and TiO2 support. After doping Pb, the surface concentration of Ce on CT and CWT fell to a different extent. It was found that the sequence in the surface concentration of Ce on the four samples was not absolutely in line with that of their activities. However, it was interesting that despite lower surface Ce concentration on Pb-CWT, the surface W concentration increased compared with the fresh CWT sample. It could be deduced that the positive role of W on catalytic activity might offset the mutual effect of Pb and active Ce species. Fig. 4 (A) illustrates the XPS spectra of Pb 4f . Two peaks at 143.5 and 138.8 eV over two poisoning samples were ascribed to Pb 4f5/2 and Pb 4f7/2, respectively. This demonstrated that Pb species existed as Pb2+ on the catalyst surface [31]. Fig. 4(B) shows the XPS spectra of W 4f over the CWT and Pb-CWT. Two peaks at 37.6 (W 4f5/2) and 35.8 eV (W 4f7/2) were detected over CWT catalyst. It indicated that W species existed in W6+ state on the surface of CWT [31]. The BE values weren't changed with the introduction of Pb. This suggested that the existent form of W species wasn't altered by Pb. The Ti 2p XPS spectra of all samples are illustrated in Fig. 4(C). For the CWT and CT, two evident peaks at about 464.4 and 458.6 eV could be, respectively ascribed to Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2. Accordingly, Ti existed as Ti4+ state on the catalyst surface [31]. As for the two poisoning catalysts, the Ti 2p BE values weren't changed significantly. This indicated that the chemical state of Ti wasn't altered by Pb, as the BE values of Ti4+was 1.8 eV higher than values of Ti3+ [31]. Consequently, the existence form of Ti (Ti4+) didn't change over Pb-CWT and Pb-CT. The Ce 3d XPS patterns of the fresh and Pb-poisoning catalysts are shown in Fig. 4(D), which can be deconvolved to 8 overlapping bands. The labeled v′ and u′ peaks could be ascribed to surface Ce3+ in accordance with the electron arrangement of 3d104f1. The rest of the peaks belonged to surface Ce4+ coinciding with the electron arrangement of 3d104f0 [32,33]. The relative ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) was quantified by the area integral of the peaks representing Ce3+ and Ce4+, and the consequences are presented in Table 2. As for the fresh CWT and CT, the ratios of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) were 0.45 and 0.43, respectively. The doping of W could increase the Ce3+ concentration on the surface of CT. After Pb was loaded on CT and CWT, their Ce3+ ratios decreased at different levels. It indicated that the transformation of Ce4+ to Ce3+ was suppressed by PbO, thereby contributing to the decrease in the amount of Ce3+/Ce4+ redox couples. This also meant that the interaction between PbO and Ce species impaired the reducibility of the fresh catalysts. In addition, compared with Pb-CT, the Ce3+ ratio was higher over Pb-CWT. It illustrated that W could play a positive role on the shift from Ce4+to Ce3+. It is well-established that the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ is accompanied by the formation of surface chemisorbed oxygen and oxygen vacancies [8,34], which can accelerate the adsorption and activation of NO or NH3 species [35]. It was interesting to note that the order of the ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) over the four samples was exactly in keeping with that of their catalytic activities. Consequently, W enhanced the ability of CT to resist Pb-poisoning. As presented in Fig. 4(E), the O 1 s XPS spectra could be deconvolved into three distinct bands. The band of 527.7–530.6 eV was originated from lattice oxygen (Oα), 530.6–531.1 eV belonged to surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ), and 531.1–533.5 eV was assigned to hydroxyl group or surface adsorbed water species (Oγ) [36,37]. It is widely accepted that Oβ is more active than Oα and Oγ during SCR process because of its higher mobility, thus promoting the oxidation of NO to NO2 [38,39]. From Table 2, it could be seen that the Oβ/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) ratio over CT catalyst was 0.32 and ascended to 0.37 by the modification of W. As for the Pb-CT, the ratio of Oβ/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) decreased to 0.21, which was lower than that of Pb-CWT (0.28). Combining with the analysis above, the presence of Ce3+ manifested the formation of oxygen vacancies and unsaturated chemical bonds, thereby capturing more chemisorbed oxygen on the surface of catalysts. It was reasonable that the doping of W would result in the presence of more surface chemisorbed oxygen and Ce3+ over CT, which could be considered as major factors which accounted for the enhanced Pb resistance by W. 3.5 H2-TPR results To research the redox properties of the four samples in SCR reaction, H2-TPR experiments were conducted and the consequences are exhibited in Fig. 5 . As for the CT, an evident peak appeared in 462 °C was detected, which was possibly interpreted as the surface Ce4+ reduction to Ce3+ [34,40]. It could be seen that the temperature of main reduction band moved to 534 °C with the presence of W, representing the co-reduction of surface Ce4+ and W6+ [41]. The reduction peak temperatures of Pb-CWT and Pb-CT decreased to 501 and 437 °C, respectively. It was suggestive of the existence of more Ce4+ over two poisoning samples [8], which agreed well with the XPS results. In addition, the H2 consumption of CWT (119.7 ml/g) was much higher than that of CT (107.3 ml/g), as summarized in Table 3 . It implied that W could strengthen the redox property of CT considerably. The H2 consumption of Pb-CWT (85.8 ml/g) decreased greatly in comparison with CWT, while it was still higher than that of Pb-CT (64.4 ml/g). It meant that W could play a positive role in alleviating the degradation of the redox property of CT due to Pb. 3.6 NH3-TPD results The NH3-TPD curves of the fresh and Pb-poisoning samples are presented in Fig. 6 , and their surface acidities calculated according to the NH3-TPD peak areas are listed in Table 4 . CT exhibited two NH3 desorption peaks. The broad low-temperature peak could be assigned to NH3 desorption from weak and medium acid sites [23]. The small high-temperature peak could be due to NH3 desorption from strong acid sites [42,43]. With regard to the fresh samples, the amount of NH3 desorbed from CT increased noticeably after doping W, which could be attributed to the interaction among Ce species, W species and TiO2 support. It implied stronger surface acidity of CWT, which contributed to promoting its catalytic activity. The doping of PbO caused a remarkable decline in the areas of the two peaks for CT and CWT, especially the low-temperature peak on behalf of weak and medium acid sites (see Table 4). It meant that there existed the strong reciprocity between Pb and acid sites, which restrained NH3 absorption on catalyst surface. As shown in Table 4, the total acidities of the four samples decreased in the following order: CWT > CT > Pb-CWT > Pb-CT, which was in good agreement with the variation of the catalytic activities over the four samples. It is widely accepted that the adsorption of NH3 is the first step of NH3-SCR reaction and depends heavily on the acidity of catalyst [23]. The addition of W could significantly reduce the loss of acid sites on CT by PbO and more catalytic activities were retained. 3.7 In situ DRIFT results 3.7.1 NH3 adsorption To ascertain the acid sites of the fresh and Pb-poisoning samples, in situ DRIFT characterizations of NH3 adsorption were conducted and the consequences are presented in Fig. 7 . As for the CT sample (see Fig. 7(B)), the bands appearing at 1673 and 1471 cm−1 were assigned to NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites, while the peaks at 1590, 1224 and 1163 cm−1 were ascribed to coordinated NH3 linked to Lewis acid sites [8,41, 44–46]. Several NH3 adsorption peaks could be also detected on CWT sample (Fig. 7(A)), including NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites (1667, 1447 cm−1) and coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid sites (1590, 1235, 1180 cm−1) [41,44–46]. Compared with the NH3 adsorption spectra over CT and CWT, the band intensities of Lewis acid sites were barely changed by the addition of W, while the band intensities of Brønsted acid sites increased remarkably. As for Pb-CT in Fig. 7(D), the peaks owing to Brønsted acid sites completely disappeared and only two bands due to Lewis acid sites (1595, 1160 cm−1) were recorded. In comparison, there still existed abundant acid sites for NH3 adsorption over Pb-CWT (1674, 1597, 1463, 1208 and 1161 cm−1), as shown in Fig. 7(C). It was apparent that the introduction of W could relieve the poisoning effect of Pb on the acid sites of CT. Considering that the biggest gap of the catalytic activities between the fresh and Pb-poisoning samples was present at 250 °C (see Fig. 1), the relative ratio of NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites to that on Lewis acid sites on the four samples was calculated in view of their NH3-desorption peak area of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in the DRIFT spectra at 250 °C. It decreased in the following sequence: CWT(1.67) > CT(1.17) > Pb-CWT(0.22) > Pb-CT(0), which had the same tendency as the variation of their activities. It suggested the change in the distribution of acid sites on the four samples. The addition of W could increase the amount of acid sites on CT, especially Brønsted acid sites. The presence of Pb gave rise to the decrease in the acidity of CT and CWT, and Brønsted acid sites completely vanished on Pb-CT. However, more acid sites (particularly Brønsted acid sites) were retained due to the addition of W when Pb was present. According to the above XPS results, the addition of W increased the amount of surface Ce3+ species over CT catalyst, which could act as Brønsted acid sites [8,14]. On the other hand, the well dispersed W species were also reported to be the main contributors of Brønsted acid sites [47]. Therefore, the increased acid sites was reasonably a critical factor accounting for the enhanced Pb resistance of CT catalyst by W. 3.7.2 NO+O2 co-adsorption The NO x adsorption properties over the fresh and Pb-poisoning catalysts were obtained using in situ DRIFT experiments. As exhibited in Fig. 8 (B), three adsorption bands of NO x species were observed over CT, including adsorbed NO2 (1610 cm−1) and bidentate nitrates (1520, 1274 cm−1) [44,46,48]. For the CWT catalyst (see Fig. 8(A)), the new peaks at 1602 and 1470 cm−1 emerged and could be, respectively owing to adsorbed NO2 and monodentate nitrates [48,49]. It was worth noting that the band intensity attributed to adsorbed NO2 over CWT was much higher than that of CT. This manifested that the oxidation of NO to NO2 was significantly improved after W addition. As for the two poisoning samples, the band intensities significantly weakened compared to those of fresh samples (especially for the bands due to adsorbed NO2). It suggested that the NO x adsorption and the oxidation of NO to NO2 were suppressed due to the presence of PbO. By contrast, the band intensities of Pb-CWT were still much higher than that of Pb-CT. It is well accepted that NO oxidation to NO2 facilitates the SCR process through the “fast SCR” pathway [50]. Accordingly, it could be inferred that the introduction of W could promote the NO x adsorption and the oxidation of NO to NO2 over CT catalyst, resulting in the enhanced resistance to Pb poisoning. This was probably related to the increased surface chemisorbed oxygen with the presence of W, as analyzed in XPS. 3.7.3 NH3 pre-adsorption and then NO+O2 The in situ DRIFT investigation of all samples with pre-adsorbed NH3 species upon exposing in NO+O2 were carried out at 200 °C to study the reactive activation of adsorbed NH3 during the NH3-SCR process, and the results are presented as Fig. 9 . The DRIFT curves of the NH3 adsorption on the four samples was compared. The CWT sample exhibited several bands ascribed to coordinated NH3 bonded to Lewis acid sites (1590, 1235, 1180 cm−1) and NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites (1667, 1447 cm−1) [44–46], as shown in Fig. 9(A). CT showed similar bands to CWT (see Fig. 9(B)). By comparison, the band intensities of the two Pb-poisoning samples weakened significantly (see Fig. 9(C) and Fig. 9(D)), and the bands due to NH4 + species on Brønsted acid sites even disappeared completely on CT (see Fig. 9(D)). In the light of the NH3-adsorption peak area of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites on the four samples, their relative ratio of NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites to that on Lewis acid sites was calculated. It followed the sequence: CWT(2.56) > CT(1.64) > Pb-CWT(0.43) > Pb-CT(0), which had the same tendency as the variation of their activities. When 1000 ppm NO+3% O2 were imported into the DRIFT cell, all the peaks disappeared immediately within 2 min on CWT. Afterwards, three adsorption peaks owing to NO x species (1587, 1557, 1230 cm−1) [46,48] were observed and grew over time. This manifested that all these adsorbed NH3 species could take part in the NH3-SCR process over CWT. Similar to CWT, the adsorbed NH3 species on CT all presented high reactivity (see Fig. 9(B)). Therefore, it was reasonable to conclude that the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism occurred on the two fresh samples surface in the SCR process [51]. Similar conclusions could be drawn over two poisoning samples, as presented in Fig. 9(C) and (D). Taking the NH3 adsorption results in 3.7.1 into consideration, it could be found that the doping of PbO restrained the NH3 adsorption over the CT and CWT catalyst samples, but the reactivity of the adsorbed NH3 species was not changed. 3.7.4 NO+O2 pre-adsorption and then NH3 In this section, the catalyst were primarily swept by 1000 ppm NO+3% O2 (200 °C, 30 min). Afterwards, 1000 ppm NH3 was added into the DRIFT cell after purged by N2 (15 min). As the extending of time, the DRIFT spectra were detected. Some peaks originated from adsorbed NO x species (1601, 1470, 1275 cm−1) [46, 48] were detected in the spectra of the fresh CWT sample after exposing in NO+O2 for 30 min. And all the bands vanished in two minutes after passing NH3. Soon afterwards, the bands assigned to NH3 adsorption (1590, 1447, 1245 and 1182 cm−1) appeared [44-46]. Similar conclusions could be found over the fresh CT sample (see Fig. 10 (B)). A conclusion could be drawn that all adsorbed NO x species were highly active during the NH3-SCR process over the two fresh catalysts. Therefore, the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism existed over two fresh test samples in NH3-SCR process [51]. The DRIFT spectra of the Pb-CT and Pb-CWT catalyst samples are, respectively illustrated in Fig. 10(C) and (D). Likewise, the reactivity of adsorbed NO x species wasn't weakened by the doping of PbO although the adsorption of NO x species was inhibited, as analyzed in Section 3.7.2 . In summary, the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism over the fresh CWT and CT wasn't altered by the doping of PbO, which complied with both E-R mechanism and L-H mechanisms. 3.8 DFT study DFT calculations were used to study NH3 adsorption on Brønsted acid sites at the atomic level. Fig. 11 shows the optimized structures of the fresh and Pb-poisoned catalysts. It could be seen that PbO adsorption had little influence on the surface configuration of CT and CWT catalysts. The adsorption energy of NH3 on the different samples and the corresponding optimized structures are shown in Fig. 12 . The E ad of CWT was smaller than the E ad of CT, indicating that NH3 was more easily to adsorb on the CWT surface. In addition, the adsorption of NH3 on Pb-CWT emitted more heat than that on Pb-CT. It implied that the effect of PbO on CWT was less than CT. These conclusions meant that CWT had a better capacity to resist Pb poisoning than CT, which was consistent with the NH3-TPD and in situ DRIFT results. 3.9 Reaction mechanism According to the analysis of in situ DRIFT and DFT calculation, it could be concluded that both E-R Eq. (1)–((3)) and L-H Eq. (4)–((6)) mechanisms occurred over CWT and CT in the NH3-SCR process. As for the Pb-CWT and Pb-CT catalyst samples, the adsorption of NH3 and NO x species was inhibited to some extent, while the reactive mechanism wasn't altered by the deposition of PbO. (a) E-R mechanism (1) N H 3 ( a ) → C e 3 + , W s p e c i e s N H 4 + ( a ) (2) N H 4 + ( a ) → S u r f a c e O N H 2 ( a ) + 2 H + + e (3) N H 2 ( a ) + N O ( g ) → N H 2 N O ( a ) → N 2 + H 2 O (b) L-H mechanism (4) N O ( g ) + O ( s u r f ) → N O 2 ( a ) (5) N H 3 ( g ) → C e 4 + N H 3 ( a ) (6) N H 3 ( a ) + N O 2 ( a ) + N O ( g ) → N 2 + H 2 O From NH3 adsorption in situ DRIFT, Brønsted acid sites acted as the dominant role during the NH3-SCR process on CT catalyst. On the one hand, the transformation from Ce4+ to Ce3+ over CT was extensively promoted by the modification of W, as analyzed in the XPS and H2-TPR. This supplied more Brønsted acid sites for NH3 adsorption [8,14]. On the other hand, the highly dispersed W species could also supply Brønsted acid sites [47]. Therefore, Eq. (1) and (2) in the E-R mechanism were accelerated, as the amount of Brønsted acid sites increased significantly due to the introduction of W. This would significantly weaken the deactivation of CT by PbO. The XPS analysis of O 1 s revealed that W addition contributed to the generation of surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ), which boosted the oxidation of NO to NO2 over the CT catalyst. This indicated that reaction (4) was accelerated, as demonstrated in NO+O2 co-adsorption in situ DRIFT. Thus reaction (6) in the L-H mechanism was facilitated, resulting in the superior ability to resist Pb poisoning of CWT. According to all the analysis results, a possible principle scheme of the enhanced Pb resistance by W was exhibited in Fig. 13 . 4 Conclusion The modification of CT by W could greatly enhance its ability to resist Pb poisoning. The BET analysis indicated that the introduction of W increased the BET surface area and total pore volume, yet it was not the critical factor accounting for the enhanced Pb resistance by W. The XRD results revealed that the modification of W didn't change the crystal structures of CT catalyst. Based on the XPS and H2-TPR analysis, the transformation of Ce4+ to Ce3+ was greatly facilitated owing to the presence of W. Then the increased surface Ce3+ along with the well dispersed W species provided more Brønsted acid sites for the NH3 adsorption over CT catalyst. Furthermore, the oxidation of NO to NO2 was dramatically improved by W, which resulted from the increased surface chemisorbed oxygen (XPS). For the foregoing reasons, these possibly improve the Pb resistance of CT by W. The NH3-SCR reaction of CWT and CT samples occurred via the E-R and L-H mechanism according to in situ DRIFT analysis. The deposition of PbO merely inhibited the NH3 and NO x adsorption, while the NH3-SCR mechanism wasn't changed. coredata.dc:description: The novel CeO2/TiO2 catalysts were modified by W in this work. It revealed that W modification could significantly facilitate the capacity of CeO2/TiO2 catalyst for resisting Pb poisoning. And various characterizations were applied to explore the underlying resistance mechanism. XPS and H2-TPR analysis revealed that the W modification promoted the transformation from surface Ce4+ to Ce3+. Then the increased surface Ce3+ along with highly dispersed W species provided more Brønsted acid sites for NH3 adsorption on the surface of CeO2/TiO2 catalyst (NH3-TPD and DFT). By XPS and NO+O2 co-adsorption results, the oxidation of NO to NO2 was motivated due to the increased surface chemisorbed oxygen. Furthermore, both E-R and L-H mechanisms were suitable for the NH3-SCR reaction over CWT and CT catalysts according to in situ DRIFT analysis. The deposition of PbO merely inhibited the NH3 and NO x adsorption, while the NH3-SCR mechanism wasn't changed.
coredata.dc:title: The enhanced Pb resistance of CeO2/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 by the modification with W
